p: The doses and concentrations required to kill 50% of ant populations ranged from 3.48 to 8.18 μg/mg, and from 0.59 to 2.15 μg/mg, respectively. The essential oils were more toxic to the ants than their isolated compounds ( Table 2 and Table 3). Essential oils of the chemotypes β-caryophyllene and calamusenone were about 1.9 and 3.8 times ( A. balzani) and 1.3 and 1.3 times ( A. sexdens rubropilosa) more potent than their respective isolated compounds when applied via contact ( Table 2). In the exposure via fumigation, isolated compounds were not efficient in ants control ( Table 3). The higher steepness of the curves of lethal dose and concentration of the chemotype calamusenone resulted in low LDs 90 and LCs 90, except for A. sexdens rubropilosa via contact ( Table 2 and Table 3).
